DOCNAME: CASE OF RADIO ABC v. AUSTRIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . Radio ORG is a non - profit - making association whose registered address is in GPE . On CARDINAL DATE it applied to the ORG and ORG ( Post- und Telegraphendirektion ) for GPE , GPE and ORG for a licence to set up and operate a radio station and for allocation of a frequency on which it could broadcast programmes to the GPE region .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused the above application . Relying on LAW guaranteeing the independence of broadcasting ( “ LAW ” , see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , which provided that activities of this type had to be authorised by federal legislation , it noted that such legislation had been enacted only in respect of ORG ( Österreichischer Rundfunk , “ the ORG ” ) . Consequently , only the latter could operate in the field concerned .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG and ORG ( Generaldirektion für die Post- PERSON ) dismissed an appeal by the applicant . It observed in particular that in its judgment of DATE ORG Verfassungsgerichtshof ) had held that the ORG ’s monopoly was compatible with LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . Radio ORG then applied to ORG , arguing in particular that ORG decision was in breach of LAW . It accepted that LAW to require the licensing of broadcasting enterprises , but submitted that since no such procedure had been laid down in NORP law everyone had the right to broadcast freely .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to consider the application , holding that , regard being had to its judgment of DATE , this did not have sufficient prospects of success .

CARDINAL . After the entry into force , on DATE , of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , the applicant association lodged CARDINAL applications on CARDINAL DATE in each of which it asked to be allocated one of the CARDINAL frequencies reserved for private broadcasters in the GPE region . On DATE ORG ( Regionalradiobehörde ) gave CARDINAL separate decisions refusing these applications on the ground that , regard being had to the requirements of section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW , ORG programmes were too specialised for it to be able to give them priority over those of other applicants . ORG then appealed against these decisions to ORG .

CARDINAL . As several other appeals of the same type had been lodged with it , ORG began proceedings of its own motion , on DATE , to review the constitutionality of section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) to ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . On DATE it annulled , with immediate effect , these provisions and the frequency allocation plan based on them ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , thereby invalidating the decisions concerning the appellants taken by ORG . ORG held that the annulled provisions contravened the principle of legality ( PERSON ) , since the conditions for their application were not indicated with sufficient precision . As a result , it continued , there was no longer any legal basis on which operating licences could be granted to radio stations , so that a situation incompatible with the LAW had been brought into being .

CARDINAL . According to ORG ) of CARDINAL DATE , “ the right to set up and operate telecommunications installations ( Fernmeldeanlagen ) is vested exclusively in the federal authorities ( GPE ) ” ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) . The latter may however confer on natural or legal persons the power to exercise that right in respect of specific installations ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) . No licence is required in certain circumstances , including the setting up of an installation within the confines of a private property ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The Ministerial Ordinance of CARDINAL DATE concerning private telecommunications installations ( PERSON für PERSON über PERSON ) lays down , inter alia , the conditions for setting up and operating private telecommunications installations subject to federal supervision . According to the case - law , it can not however constitute the legal basis for the grant of licences .
CARDINAL . According to section CARDINAL of LAW of DATE guaranteeing the independence of broadcasting ( GPE über die GPE der ORG ) ,

CARDINAL . Broadcasting shall be governed by more detailed rules to be set out in a federal law . Such a law must inter alia contain provisions guaranteeing the objectivity and impartiality of reporting , the diversity of opinions , balanced programming and the independence of persons and bodies responsible for carrying out the duties defined in paragraph CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . Broadcasting within the meaning of paragraph CARDINAL shall be a public service . ”
CARDINAL . The Law of DATE on ORG ( Bundesgesetz über die PERSON ORG ) established ORG with the status of an autonomous public - law corporation .

It is under a duty to provide comprehensive news coverage of major political , economic , cultural and sporting events ; to this end , it has to broadcast , in compliance with the requirements of objectivity and diversity of views , in particular current affairs , news reports , commentaries and critical opinions ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( CARDINAL ) ) , and to do so via CARDINAL television channels and CARDINAL radio stations , CARDINAL of which must be a regional station ( section CARDINAL ) . Broadcasting time must be allocated to the political parties represented in the national parliament and to representative associations ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .

A supervisory board ( ORG ) rules on all disputes concerning the application of the above - mentioned law which fall outside the jurisdiction of an administrative authority or court ( sections CARDINAL and DATE ) . It is composed of CARDINAL independent members , including CARDINAL judges , appointed for terms of DATE by the President of the Republic on the proposal of the federal government .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG held that the freedom to set up and operate radio and television broadcasting stations was subject to the powers accorded to the legislature under paragraph CARDINAL in fine and paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL of the Convention ( Gesetzesvorbehalt ) . LAW had instituted a system which made all activity of this type subject to the grant of a licence by the federal legislature . This system was intended to ensure objectivity and diversity of opinions ( ORG ) , and would be ineffective if it were possible for everybody to obtain the requisite authorisation . As matters stood , the right to broadcast was restricted to the ORG , as no implementing legislation had been enacted in addition to the law governing that organisation ( see ORG and Others v. GPE judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL–CARDINAL , § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The Regional Broadcasting Law of DATE ( NORP ) , which came into force on DATE , governs the licensing of local and regional radio stations . Before the judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) section CARDINAL provided :

“ CARDINAL . In agreement with ORG ( Hauptausschuß des Nationalrates ) , the Federal Minister for ORG and Transport shall , by means of an ordinance ( the frequency allocation plan PERSON ) , allocate terrestrial sound radio broadcasting capacities ( drahtlose terrestrische GPE für GPE ) , defined in terms of frequency and broadcasting location , to ORG and radio stations ( Programmveranstalter ) .
CARDINAL . NORP In making the above allocation , the Federal Minister for Economic Affairs and Transport shall ensure :
( CARDINAL ) that there is no impediment to performance by ORG of the tasks imposed on it by law in the field of sound radio broadcasts ;
( CARDINAL ) that radio stations are able to reach the widest possible audience within any CARDINAL Land ; and
( CARDINAL ) that attention is paid to the needs of local sound radio .

CARDINAL . In the above - mentioned frequency allocation plan the Federal Minister for ORG and Transport shall , after consulting the ORG concerned and in agreement with ORG , assign in accordance with paragraph CARDINAL , sub - paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL , each of the frequencies and broadcasting locations available for use by radio stations to an individual licence to broadcast within the Länder . In so doing he shall have particular regard to local topography , population density , technical parameters and GPE ’s international obligations in the field of telecommunications .

CARDINAL . NORP In urgent individual cases the telecommunications authorities ( PERSON ) may take decisions at variance with the frequency allocation plan , provided that within DATE the plan is modified accordingly in conformity with paragraph CARDINAL . ”

Section CARDINAL requires the programmes of private radio stations to respect the principles of objectivity and diversity of opinion and to reflect the public , cultural and economic life of the region in which they are broadcast . Section CARDINAL instituted regional broadcasting authorities ( Regional - radiobehörde ) . Under section QUANTITY ( CARDINAL ) , where a number of private broadcasters satisfying the statutory conditions apply for a licence , the regional broadcasting authority must give priority to the CARDINAL which comes closest to achieving the objectives laid down in the PERSON , for example by reflecting a greater diversity of opinion .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL of section CARDINAL null and void ; accordingly , the frequency allocation plan based on them was likewise void .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the amendments replacing the annulled provisions came into force .
